thread.title: Sir David Attenborough says Brexit supporters 'probably don't understand it' - Leicester Mercury

author: Dan Martin
title: Sir David Attenborough says Brexit supporters 'probably don't understand it' - Leicester Mercury
text:
News Sir David Attenborough says Brexit supporters 'probably don't understand it' But he added: "Why am I going on about this? I'm not a political chap. I know about bugs." Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Comments 
Sir David Attenborough has labeled the EU referendum 'an abrogation of the principles of parliamentary democracy'. 
The renowned naturalist and broadcaster turned his attention to politics in a recent interview he did with Greenpeace on his latest work and climate change. 
Sir David, who grew up in Leicester and developed his love of nature while roaming the surrounding countryside with his brother Richard, cited a quote from leading Tory Brexit campaigner Michael Gove. Read More 
Mr Gove, now the Secretary of State for the Environment, said: "I think that the people of this country have had enough of experts," during the campaign. Michael Gove - unimpressed by experts 
Sir David said: "That is a cry from someone who doesn't understand what they are saying. 
"That's what that means. Someone has told them something they don't like and which they probably don't understand. 
"That's not an evil necessarily. There's quite a lot I don't understand and quite a lot of people I don't like. 
"It is a knee-jerk thing but it doesn't bear examination for a micro-second." 
The 91-year-old also admitted he himself did not understand the political and economic implications of Brexit. Read More Andrew Bridgen - 'The media is failing to report Brexit properly' 
He said David Cameron's decision to allow the referendum was 'an abrogation of the principle of parliamentary democracy.' 
He added: "We didn't know the facts. I still don't know the facts. All I know is that it is much more complicated than I thought." 
He said: "Philosophically I would rather people embrace one another rather than spat in one another's eyes." 
Sir David said internationalism was needed to tackle major issues such as climate change adding: "We need more internationalism not less, more talking not less, more agreement not less - and less (sic) frontiers." 
He added: "Why am I going on about this? I'm not a political chap. I know about bugs." Read More
